newsitem.title: CANADA: Canadian T-bills open weaker on rate hike concern.
newsitem.headline: Canadian T-bills open weaker on rate hike concern.

text.p: Canadian T-bills opened weaker for a second straight session on Friday as concern about a near-term Bank of Canada rate hike sent yields higher, analysts said.

"It looks like the market is projecting an impending rate hike by the bank. I think they're pricing it in. There really isn't anything more than that," said Walter Posiewko, a money market trader with Royal Bank Investment Management.
Canada's three-month cash T-bill softened to yield 3.33 percent from 3.32 percent at the close of trading on Thursday.

Analysts said recent signs of strength in the economy, combined some weakness in the currency, have spurred speculation of a near-term Bank of Canada rate hike. Last month the Bank of Canada hiked interest rates by 25 basis points, its first such move in more than two years.
"It looks like its talking itself into believing there's some kind of an impending rate hike, and they're just adjusting rates to reflect that," said Posiewko.
Activity in the Canadian money market during the past week has been muted ahead of 0900 EDT/1300 GMT, when the Bank of Canada traditional announces rate hikes.

Posiewko said he thought talk of a rate hike was overdone and while there has been some currency weakness and a move up in the consumer prices index, it is not enough to send rates higher. The Canadian consumer price index report for June out on Thursday showed the so-called core CPI rose 0.2 percent on the month and 2.0 percent on the year.
In other prices, the six-month when-issued T-bill weakened to yield 3.70 percent from a 3.69 percent on Thursday.
The one-year T-bill traded unchanged to yield 4.18 percent.
The call loan or overnight lending rate traded at 3.25 percent, in the middle of the Bank of Canada's 3.0-3.5 percent target range.
